title: RFU Junior Vase
text:
The RFU Junior Vase is a <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> national knockout cup competition in England run by the <a href="Rugby%20Football%20Union">Rugby Football Union</a>, which has been competed for since 1990.<ref name="Provincial Insurance Cup 1/"></ref> It is mostly contested by 1st XV teams at level 9 of the <a href="English%20rugby%20union%20system">English rugby union system</a>, although sides as low as level 12 or even outside the league system can sometimes enter. The competition is a national one, but split into regions until the national semi-finals with the final being held at <a href="Twickenham%20Stadium">Twickenham Stadium</a> in <a href="London">London</a>. Presently, the RFU Junior Vase is the fifth most important club cup competition in England, behind the <a href="Premiership%20Rugby%20Cup">Premiership Rugby Cup</a>, <a href="RFU%20Championship%20Cup">RFU Championship Cup</a>, <a href="RFU%20Intermediate%20Cup">RFU Intermediate Cup</a> and <a href="RFU%20Senior%20Vase">RFU Senior Vase</a>.
History.
The Vase was first contested for during the 1990–91 season, when it was known as the Provincial Insurance Cup (named after its sponsors). It was introduced by the <a href="Rugby%20Football%20Union">RFU</a> to provide a national cup competition for junior clubs in the <a href="English%20rugby%20union%20system">English rugby union system</a> not already competing in the <a href="Anglo-Welsh%20Cup">Pilkington Cup</a>, with a number of knock-out rounds culminating in the final held at <a href="Twickenham%20Stadium">Twickenham Stadium</a>. The competition would have a number of different sponsors over the course of its history, including Provincial Insurance, <a href="Pilkington">Pilkington</a>, NPI, <a href="Tetley%27s%20Brewery">Tetley's Brewery</a>, <a href="Powergen">Powergen</a> and <a href="EDF%20Energy">EDF Energy</a>. Since the 2009–10 season the competition has been known as the RFU Junior Vase and is competed for by clubs playing in at level 9 of the league system. It is currently un-sponsored.
Current format.
The rounds are contested on a regional basis between the four regional unions (<a href="Rugby%20Football%20Union%20Northern%20Division">North</a>, <a href="Rugby%20Football%20Union%20Midland%20Division">Midlands</a>, <a href="London%20and%20South%20East%20Division%20Rugby%20Football%20Union">London & South East</a>, South West) until the semi-finals, where the winner of each region enters the national competition, with the winner of each semi-final meeting at the final at Twickenham Stadium. Each region has a different qualification method (more detail on this below) and at the end of this qualification there are four regional champions who play in the national semi-finals the ground being one of the semi-finalist's home. The semi-finals pairings are London & South East against South West and Midlands against North.
North.
The format for northern teams involved in the RFU Junior Vase is a league-cup hybrid with each county union in the region typically selecting one representative each (although Cheshire have two representatives for the 2018–19 competition). The first stage features a mini league with clubs from <a href="Cheshire%20Rugby%20Football%20Union">Cheshire</a> and <a href="Lancashire%20County%20Rugby%20Football%20Union">Lancashire</a> meeting in one pool and clubs from <a href="Durham%20County%20Rugby%20Football%20Union">Durham County</a>, <a href="Northumberland%20Rugby%20Football%20Union">Northumberland</a> and <a href="Yorkshire%20Rugby%20Football%20Union">Yorkshire</a>, meeting in the other, each side playing 2 games each. The winners of each group then meet in the north final to determine who goes forward to the national semi-finals. The competition involves representative teams from the following unions and level 9-10 leagues:
Midlands.
The format for Midlands teams involved in the RFU Junior Vase is a direct knockout cup with a 1st round, 2nd round, 3rd round, semi-finals and final, with all sides from the eligible leagues taking part. The winner of the final goes forward to the national semi-finals. The competition involves unions and clubs from the following level 9-10 leagues:
London and South East.
As with the Midlands the format for London and South East teams involved in the RFU Junior Vase is a direct knockout cup with a 1st round, 2nd round, 3rd round, semi-finals and final, with all eligible teams taking part. The winner of the final goes forward to the national semi-finals. The competition involves 1st XV teams from the following unions and level 9-12 leagues:
South West.
The format for the south-west teams in the RFU Junior Vase is more complex with different methods of qualification decided on by the county unions that they represent. Clubs that are affiliated with <a href="Dorset%20and%20Wilts%20Rugby%20Football%20Union">Dorset & Wilts</a> and <a href="Gloucestershire%20Rugby%20Football%20Union">Gloucestershire</a> play in county based knock-out competitions first. The winners of the Dorset & Wilts competition then plays in the Southern Counties semi-finals against representatives from <a href="Berkshire%20Rugby%20Football%20Union">Berkshire</a>, <a href="Buckinghamshire%20Rugby%20Football%20Union">Buckinghamshire</a> and <a href="Oxfordshire%20Rugby%20Football%20Union">Oxfordshire</a>, while the Gloucestershire winners play in the South West Counties semi-finals against representative from <a href="Rugby%20union%20in%20Cornwall">Cornwall</a>, <a href="Devon%20Rugby%20Football%20Union">Devon</a> and <a href="Somerset%20Rugby%20Football%20Union">Somerset</a>, with the winners then meeting in a regional final. Finally, the Southern Counties and South West Counties winners meet to determine qualification for the national semi-finals. Teams involved (1st XV only) are typically from the following unions and level 9-12 leagues:
